December 18, 2011: Fiction
THE DROP, by Michael Connelly. (Little, Brown, $27.99.) Harry Bosch of the L.A.P.D.
uncovers both the operations of a sadistic killer and a political conspiracy.
11/22/63, by Stephen King. (Scribner, $35.) An English teacher travels back to 1958
by way of a time portal in a Maine diner. His assignment is to stop Lee Harvey
Oswald.
EXPLOSIVE EIGHTEEN, by Janet Evanovich. (Bantam, $28.) After a disastrous
vacation in Hawaii, Stephanie Plum becomes the target of an international killer.
THE LITIGATORS, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $28.95.) Partners in a small law
firm take on a big case after a fast-track burnout joins them.
KILL ALEX CROSS, by James Patterson. (Little, Brown, $28.99.) Alex Cross
investigates when the president’s children are kidnapped, but the F.BI. and C.I.A.
stand in his way.
THE BEST OF ME, by Nicholas Sparks. (Grand Central, $25.99.) Twenty-five years
after their high school romance ended, a man and woman who have gone their
separate ways return to their North Carolina town for the funeral of a friend.
V IS FOR VENGEANCE, by Sue Grafton. (Marian Wood/Putnam, $27.95.) Pursuing a
shoplifter, Kinsey Millhone discovers that retail crime is run by organized gangs.
THE SCOTTISH PRISONER, by Diana Gabaldon. (Delacorte, $28.) Jamie Fraser, a
paroled Jacobite prisoner, and Lord John Grey collaborate uneasily on a mission to
Ireland.
MICRO, by Michael Crichton. (Harper/HarperCollins, $28.99.) Seven graduate
students, miniaturized by an evil entrepreneur, do battle with insects in the Hawaiian
rain forest.
ZERO DAY, by David Baldacci. (Grand Central, $27.99.) A military investigator
uncovers a conspiracy.
1Q84, by Haruki Murakami. (Knopf, $30.5.) In 1980s Tokyo, a woman who punishes
perpetrators of domestic violence has ties to an aspiring novelist with an unusual
project.
A DANCE WITH DRAGONS, by George R. R. Martin. (Bantam, $35.) After a colossal
battle, the Seven Kingdoms face new threats; Book 5 of "A Song of Ice and Fire."
THE MARRIAGE PLOT, by Jeffrey Eugenides. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $28.) Three
Brown graduates in the early 1980s wrestle with love, religion and coming of age.
DEVIL'S GATE, by Clive Cussler and Graham Brown. (Putnam, $27.95.) In the ninth
NUMA Files novel, Kurt Austin and his crew uncover a plan to blackmail major
December 18, 2011
Non-Fiction
STEVE JOBS, by Walter Isaacson. (Simon & Schuster, $35.) A biography of the
recently deceased entrepreneur.
KILLING LINCOLN, by Bill O'Reilly and Martin Dugard. (Holt, $28.) The heart-
stopping events surrounding the assassination of Abraham Lincoln.
BEING GEORGE WASHINGTON, by Glenn Beck and Kevin Balfe. (Threshold
Editions/Mercury Radio Arts, $26.) How Washington turned himself into the
indispensable man.
UNBROKEN, by Laura Hillenbrand. (Random House, $27.) An Olympic runner's
story of survival as a prisoner of the Japanese in World War II.
JACK KENNEDY, by Chris Matthews. (Simon & Schuster, $27.5.) An admiring
portrait.
CATHERINE THE GREAT, by Robert K. Massie. (Random House, $35.) The life
of the minor 18th-century German princess who became Empress of All the
Russias.
THINKING, FAST AND SLOW, by Daniel Kahneman. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux,
$30.) The winner of the Nobel in economic science discusses how we make
choices in business and personal life and when we can and cannot trust our
intuitions.
BACK TO WORK, by Bill Clinton. (Knopf, $23.95.) The former president argues
that cooperation between the private sector and government is necessary to
restore prosperity.
BOOMERANG, by Michael Lewis. (Norton, $25.95.) A look at some of the places
hardest hit by the financial collapse of 2008.
THEN AGAIN, by Diane Keaton. (Random House, $26.) The actress uses her
mother’s diaries as a springboard for the examination of her own life.
THROW THEM ALL OUT, by Peter Schweizer. (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, $26.)
Insider trading in Congress.
HEAVEN IS FOR REAL, by Todd Burpo with Lynn Vincent. (Thomas Nelson,
$21.99.) A boy’s encounter with Jesus and the angels.
HOW I GOT THIS WAY, by Regis Philbin. (It Books/HarperCollins, $25.99.) The
recently retired co-host of “Live! With Regis and Kelly’’ looks back.
IMPERFECT JUSTICE, by Jeff Ashton with Lisa Pulitzer. (Morrow/HarperCollins,
$26.99.) A prosecutor’s account of the Casey Anthony trial.
